Higher spectral resolution allows for a better constraint on the turbulence, although at the expense of decreased S/N. Our choice of channel width is a balance between these two competing factors. As demonstrated in Figure 2 (we expect similar results for TW Hya as in V4046 Sgr), with a channel width of 80m/s we can detect differences in the line profile, mainly in the change in peak-to-trough ratio. Channel width also feeds into our spatial resolution requirement; a broader channel encompases a larger range of keplerian/thermal/non-thermal motions within the disk leading to an overall broader image. This broader image serves to dilute our efforts to use spatial resolution to help in separating out non-thermal broadening. Our choice of 80m/s resolution allows us to distinguish the influence of turbulence on the line profile and channel maps, while ensuring high S/N detections in a reasonable amount of time.
One baseband will be centered on CO(2-1), a second will be centered on 13CO(2-1) and a third will be centered on C18O(2-1). Our main science goals involve using these lines to constrain turbulence as well as the temperature and density structure of the disk. The fourth baseband will be used for continuum observations. Dust continuum emission complements our main focus on the gas and helps with self-calibration of the data.

We request a spatial resolution of 0.3" to probe the changes in the channel maps due to turbulent broadening. Based on disk models, and experience fitting HD 163296, we find that spatial resolution plays a large role in our ability to constrain non-thermal motions below the channel spacing. As demonstrated in Figure 2 (we expect similar results for TW Hya as in V4046 Sgr), this spatial resolution will be able to distinguish the broadening due to turbulence.
While the disk diameter (~6") fits easily within the Band 6 primary beam, our desired maximum resolution will end up resolving out much of the large scale emission. To recover this component we also request observations in a compact configuration. This will ensure high S/N across the line, while the higher spatial resolution component is necessary to resolve the fine scale differences due to turbulence. We can fit ~10 beams across the radius of the disk, allowing us to accurately measure the radial profile of the emission, which depends on the radial profile of the temperature, density and turbulence.

Our sensitivity requirement is driven by the faintest of the three lines, C18O(2-1). Previous observations (e.g. Hughes et al. 2011) provide a strong guide for building protoplanetary disk models that can predict the C18O(2-1) flux given the proposed ALMA configuration. These models conservatively predict a peak flux of ~150mJy/beam. Our proposed rms sensitivity of 8mJy/beam will provide S/N~19 at the peak, and can detect flux out at the line wings and at the outer extent of the disk at the >3sigma level.
Based on our experience fitting the HD 163926 CO emission, we find that constraining the turbulence requires high S/N. Figure 2 demonstrates that with our proposed sensitivity there are clear differences in the CO 2-1 line between high and low turbulence models for V4046 Sgr; we expect similar behavior in TW Hya. We expect to be sensitive to non-thermal motion greater than 10% of the sound speed with the main isotoplogue of CO. Given that most numerical models predict turbulent motions of 30-50% of the sound speed near the CO tau=1 surface, we expect to place physically meaningful constraints on the turbulence. The S/N in the weaker isotopologues will be high enough to constrain the radial temperature and density structure, which are crucial for determining if the disk is susceptable to gravito-turbulence or baroclinic instability, two competing theories, along with MRI, for explaining the angular momentum transport within young disks. For detectable levels of turbulence, the S/N in these lines will also be high enough to measure the turbulence closer to the midplane, allowing us to build a three-dimensional view of turbulence within these disks.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Turbulence is a central component of planet formation theory, yet observational constraints on its magnitude and spatial distribution have so far been scarce. In a pilot study of HD 163296 ALMA Science Verification CO 3-2 emission we found that the high spatial resolution data were able to limit turbulence to less than 5% of the local sound speed. This upper limit is almost an order of magnitude lower than predicted from theory, but it is not clear if this result is unique to this source. Here we propose to extend the sample to include CO observations of four additional sources that cover a wide range of ionizing flux, a crucial parameter for setting the size of the MRI-active region. Additional 13CO and C18O observations will measure the temperature and density structure in the outer disk, allowing us to constrain the conditions for gravito-turbulence and baroclinic instability, two competing theories, along with MRI, for turbulence in protoplanetary disks.
